content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice little puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice clash. tested and approved.

nice one :)

when tested in IDE, i see at the end of the starting code :
puts "Upvotes"
puts "write Downvotes"

not sure if "write" is excepted here

I have two problems with this:

For many configurations the upvote rate is not naturally an integer.  Is it truncated?  Rounded?

Many configurations do not have a unique solution.  For example, assume there are 100 upvotes.  
49 downvotes -- 0.6711
50 downvotes -- 0.6667
51 downvotes -- 0.6622
No matter how you round, 2 of those will be the same to 2 digits, so there are multiple solutions.  
If only values of R that come out as integers are allowed you need to say so.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is fun and easily solvable
Nice task! Why R cannot be 50? And if so, I suggest to mention it also in the input line 2 statement as well if other constraints are also mentioned here.

Really nice problem!
You have a typo in the statement, at the Upvote Rate. You wrote "Ppvotes".

Thanks for the question. When R is 50, then number of Upvotes = number of Downvotes, and the Score must be 0. However, in this scenario, it is impossible to determine an exact number of upvotes and downvotes.

It is listed in the constraints just for completeness. When it comes to parsing input, that fact is not important (hat’s why I did not list in in the input section). What’s important when it comes to input parsing is that 80% is represented in the input as "80", not "80%" or "0.8".

Thanks for the comment. Since the statement does not say anything about it, rounding or truncation is not needed (and IMO should not be assumed).

I have made sure that all of the input configurations have been chosen such that there’s exactly one pair of integers (U, D) which resulted in the exact value of R (without any rounding or truncation).
It is not expected… I updated the stub generator.

If only cases where R is an integer are allowed, the constraints should say so.  It's bad programming practice to assume that this is okay just because the visible test cases don't happen to hit it.  I was very distracted by knowing my solution would fail on most possible inputs.

I think it does not need to be said because the statement asks you to find U and D, not R. The R is given to be integer (stated in the input section).

Even with many possible solutions when rounding, it usually make sense to pick the solution that gives the closest resulting percentage. The large test case will confirm that it is indeed a workable approach.

In the Large Test Case 2, if you round the resulting percentage to the nearest integer, you will find that there are 329,467 different (U, D) values that resulted in S = 9884 and  R = 51%. However, there is only a single answer that’s closest to 51.000000%.
Then you might add one more outcome, which can be something "cannot define". Just an idea, just for fun :P,
